newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Hungary to discuss anti-inflation plans- finmin.
newsitem.headline: Hungary to discuss anti-inflation plans- finmin.

text.p: Hungary's government is likely to discuss within three weeks two alternative programmes on the reduction of inflation (CPI) in 1998, Finance Minister Peter Medgyessy told Reuters in an interview on Monday.
"This is a matter of such importance that before (the government discussion) I will ask the prime minister and the central bank president for a joint consultation," he said.

Medgyessy said the alternative programme, which includes a more radical cut, may push down year-on-year inflation to slightly below 10 percent by December 1998 in the optimal case, pending a price and wage agreement between the government, employers and employees.

He said year-on-year inflation could go down to between 16 to 17 percent by December 1997 from 18.8 percent in March. He said he would be able to give a more justified forecast in June after seeing May CPI figures.
He said the other programme for 1998 would represent a one to three percentage point smaller cut in average inflation.
Medgyessy said the ministry maintained its 18 percent average inflation forecast for 1997, compared with 23.6 percent last year.
